elements.content: The complexes formed by uranyl nitrate with the three positional isomers of sulfobenzoate and with ethanedisulfonate anions in the presence of cucurbit[6]uril (CB6) under hydrothermal conditions were investigated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. 2-Sulfobenzoate (2-SB2–) chelates the uranyl ion through one carboxylate and one sulfonate oxygen atoms in the three complexes [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)3]2·CB6·12H2O (1), [Na(CB6)(H2O)4][UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2·NO3·3H2O (2), and {[UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2Cs(CB6)(OH)(H2O)5}·2H2O (3). While 1 is a monomer, 2 and 3 display neutral dimeric [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2 units. In 2, these units are bound to the sodium ion complex of CB6 through hydrogen bonds, while, in 3, bonding of one of the uranyl water ligands to cesium gives a one-dimensional coordination polymer. 3-Sulfobenzoate (3-SB2–) gives the three-dimensional framework [(UO2)2Cs2(3-SB)3(CB6)(H2O)4.5]·7.5H2O (4), in which carboxylate groups are chelating or bridging uranyl ions, and sulfonate groups are coordinated to uranyl and cesium ions, the latter being also bound to CB6 carbonyl groups. In contrast, the para isomer 4-SB2– gives the molecular species [UO2K2(4-SB)2(CB6)(H2O)9]·11H2O (5), in which uranyl is bound to one monodentate carboxylate group from each ligand, and one sulfonate oxygen atom is bound to one of the potassium ions complexed by CB6. Ethanedisulfonate (EDS2–) was chosen as a potentially bridging, homo-difunctional ligand devoid of the strongly uranyl-binding carboxylate groups. The complex [(UO2)4(EDS)(OH)6(CB6)(H2O)2]·8H2O (6) is a three-dimensional framework with a remarkable architecture: uranyl-bridging hydroxides give rise to undulated chains which are linked to one another by bridging, tetradentate disulfonate ligands to give planar two-dimensional subunits displaying large [(UO2)8(EDS)2(OH)10] rings, and these sheets are assembled into a unique network by uranyl-bound CB6 molecules. Both frameworks 4 and 6 are novel examples of the association of uranyl–organic sheets with CB6 columns or layers, a quite frequent feature in this family of compounds.

elements.content: When reacted with uranyl ions in the presence of cucurbit[6]uril, the three positional isomers of sulfobenzoate give zero- to three-dimensional assemblies depending on the sulfonate position and the presence of additional alkali metal ions, while ethanedisulfonate yields a three-dimensional framework of quite original architecture.
elements.clean_text: When reacted with uranyl ions in the presence of cucurbit[6]uril, the three positional isomers of sulfobenzoate give zero- to three-dimensional assemblies depending on the sulfonate position and the presence of additional alkali metal ions, while ethanedisulfonate yields a three-dimensional framework of quite original architecture.

elements.content: Sulfonates are generally considered to be weak ligands, particularly when compared with the geometrically similar phosphonates, and, as a consequence, they have been quite little used in the design of metal–organic polymers or frameworks. Nonetheless, examples have been reported of extended sulfonate structures involving alkali, alkaline-earth, d-block, and 4f metal cations, and a detailed review of the architectures formed, some of them exhibiting remarkable dynamic behavior originating from the very weakness and coordination mode versatility of the sulfonate ligand, was recently published. In the case of actinide ions, few sulfonate complexes are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.32), and the overwhelming majority are molecular species involving the ubiquitous trifluoromethanesulfonate anion. However, some extended structures containing the uranyl ion have been obtained with bridging bidentate κ 2 O:Oˈ-ethane and -methanesulfonate anions, which are either one- or two-dimensional. Apart from these results, the field of sulfonate-based uranyl–organic assemblies is unexplored, which is in contrast to the present development of uranyl phosphonate chemistry, a domain that displays a very remarkable variety of structural arrangements, ranging from nanotubules to three-dimensional frameworks. Recently, in the course of an investigation of the complexes formed by cucurbiturils with uranyl ions, it was possible to obtain one- to three-dimensional uranyl–alkali metal ion heterometallic assemblies with cucurbit[6]uril (CB6, Scheme ) and the sulfonated catechol 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron) as ligands. In all the cases, the uranyl ion is chelated by one sulfonate and one phenoxide oxygen atoms, with further bonding of the second sulfonate to uranyl and/or alkali metal ions. These results seemed all the more interesting that, apart from the scarcity of uranyl sulfonate complexes, it has been impossible up to now to obtain crystals of the uranyl complex of Tiron in the absence of CB6. This points to the possibility of using the bulky and rigid CB6 molecule as an additional ligand permitting the crystallization of uranyl complexes with other sulfonates. This idea was tested by using 2-, 3-, and 4-sulfobenzoic acids, which are quite common ligands, but for which no actinide complex has ever been reported, and 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid, for which only five structures of complexes with d-block metal ions are known, and the results are reported herein.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Sulfonates are generally considered to be weak ligands, particularly when compared with the geometrically similar phosphonates, and, as a consequence, they have been quite little used in the design of metal-organic polymers or frameworks. Nonetheless, examples have been reported of extended sulfonate structures involving alkali, alkaline-earth, d-block, and 4f metal cations, and a detailed review of the architectures formed, some of them exhibiting remarkable dynamic behavior originating from the very weakness and coordination mode versatility of the sulfonate ligand, was recently published. In the case of actinide ions, few sulfonate complexes are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.32), and the overwhelming majority are molecular species involving the ubiquitous trifluoromethanesulfonate anion. However, some extended structures containing the uranyl ion have been obtained with bridging bidentate κ 2  O:Oˈ-ethane and -methanesulfonate anions, which are either one- or two-dimensional. Apart from these results, the field of sulfonate-based uranyl-organic assemblies is unexplored, which is in contrast to the present development of uranyl phosphonate chemistry, a domain that displays a very remarkable variety of structural arrangements, ranging from nanotubules to three-dimensional frameworks. Recently, in the course of an investigation of the complexes formed by cucurbiturils with uranyl ions, it was possible to obtain one- to three-dimensional uranyl-alkali metal ion heterometallic assemblies with cucurbit[6]uril (CB6, Scheme ) and the sulfonated catechol 4,5-dihydroxy-1,3-benzenedisulfonic acid (Tiron) as ligands. In all the cases, the uranyl ion is chelated by one sulfonate and one phenoxide oxygen atoms, with further bonding of the second sulfonate to uranyl and/or alkali metal ions. These results seemed all the more interesting that, apart from the scarcity of uranyl sulfonate complexes, it has been impossible up to now to obtain crystals of the uranyl complex of Tiron in the absence of CB6. This points to the possibility of using the bulky and rigid CB6 molecule as an additional ligand permitting the crystallization of uranyl complexes with other sulfonates. This idea was tested by using 2-, 3-, and 4-sulfobenzoic acids, which are quite common ligands, but for which no actinide complex has ever been reported, and 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid, for which only five structures of complexes with d-block metal ions are known, and the results are reported herein.

elements.content:
Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2·6H2O and NaNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, 2-sulfobenzoic acid cyclic anhydride (2-SBA), sodium 3-sulfobenzoate (3-SBNaH), and potassium 4-sulfobenzoate (4-SBKH) from Aldrich, and sodium 1,2-ethanedisulfonate (EDSNa2) and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate from Fluka. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Caution! Because uranium is a radioactive and chemically toxic element, uranium-containing samples must be handled with suitable care and protection.

UO2(NO3)2⋅6H2O and NaNO3 were purchased from Prolabo, CsNO3 from Acros, 2-sulfobenzoic acid cyclic anhydride (2-SBA), sodium 3-sulfobenzoate (3-SBNaH), and potassium 4-sulfobenzoate (4-SBKH) from Aldrich, and sodium 1,2-ethanedisulfonate (EDSNa2) and cucurbit[6]uril pentahydrate from Fluka. Elemental analyses were performed by Analytische Laboratorien GmbH at Lindlar, Germany.

elements.content: CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 2-SBA (18 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within one week (8 mg, 35% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal. Calcd for C50H80N24O44S2U2: C, 26.55; H, 3.57; N, 14.86; S, 2.84. Found: C, 26.72; H, 3.51; N, 15.29; S, 2.69%.

elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, and then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to at least θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some atoms in the disordered parts and/or solvent molecules. Some lattice water molecules were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and/or to account for too close contacts. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of some water molecules, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Special details are as follows:
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, and then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to at least θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis, and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Restraints on bond lengths and/or displacement parameters were applied for some atoms in the disordered parts and/or solvent molecules. Some lattice water molecules were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and/or to account for too close contacts. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps, except for those of some water molecules, and the carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were introduced at calculated positions. All hydrogen atoms were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom. Special details are as follows:

elements.content: The sodium atom and its four aqua ligands have been given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and for charge balance. The nitrate ion is disordered over an inversion center.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 2 

The sodium atom and its four aqua ligands have been given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters and for charge balance. The nitrate ion is disordered over an inversion center.

elements.content: The cesium atom and one of the water molecules attached to it were given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters. Although the nature of the anion balancing the charge of the cesium cation is uncertain, it has been supposed that the bridging atom O16, located in the CB6 cavity with an occupancy parameter of 0.5, could be a disordered hydroxide ion.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 3 

The cesium atom and one of the water molecules attached to it were given occupancy factors of 0.5 in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters. Although the nature of the anion balancing the charge of the cesium cation is uncertain, it has been supposed that the bridging atom O16, located in the CB6 cavity with an occupancy parameter of 0.5, could be a disordered hydroxide ion.

elements.content: The potassium atom K2 is affected by a large displacement parameter, possibly indicating unresolved disorder. Two of the water molecules bound to it were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters.
elements.clean_text:
Compound 5 

The potassium atom K2 is affected by a large displacement parameter, possibly indicating unresolved disorder. Two of the water molecules bound to it were given 0.5 occupancy factors in order to retain acceptable displacement parameters.

Uranyl nitrate has been reacted with 2-sulfobenzoic acid cyclic anhydride and CB6 under hydrothermal conditions either in the absence of another reactant or with addition of alkali metal nitrates, the latter being used both to increase the CB6 solubility and to possibly create bridges between the uranyl complex and CB6 units. In all cases, the sulfonic acid (2-SBH2) was generated in situ from the anhydride and it binds to uranyl in its doubly deprotonated form to give the complexes [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)3]2·CB6·12H2O (1), [Na(CB6)(H2O)4][UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2·NO3·3H2O (2), and {[UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2Cs(CB6)(OH)(H2O)5}·2H2O (3). Compound 2 was obtained in very low yield, which was not improved significantly when heating was prolonged, possibly due to ligand decomposition (decarboxylation or desulfonation). In the absence of an alkali metal, the neutral uranyl complex [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)3] and CB6 are separated (Figure ), but it is however notable that no crystal of this complex could be obtained in the absence of CB6 and under otherwise similar conditions. The uranyl ion is chelated by one carboxylate and one sulfonate oxygen atoms to give a seven-membered ring, and the other three equatorial sites are occupied by water molecules. Chelation occurs also in the sodium- and cesium-containing complexes 2 and 3, with extra bridging by the other carboxylate oxygen atom resulting in the formation of centrosymmetric dinuclear units, and with two water molecules completing the uranium coordination sphere (Figures and ). The U–O(sulfonate) bond length averaged over all three compounds, 2.384(9) Å, matches the average of 2.38(2) Å for the uranyl sulfonate complexes reported in the CSD. The average U–O(carboxylate) and U–O(water) bond lengths, 2.37(3) and 2.39(3) Å, respectively, are unexceptional. In all cases, the carboxylate group is tilted with respect to the aromatic ring, with dihedral angles of 42.4(2), 49.3(5), and 48.5(7)°, respectively. The uranyl ion is located on one side of the aromatic ring, and the dihedral angle between the uranyl mean equatorial plane and the ring amounts to 65.75(10), 89.52(12), and 88.19(15)° in 1–3, respectively, the rings being thus nearly perpendicular to the mean equatorial plane of the dinuclear complexes. Compounds 2 and 3 have very similar unit cell parameters and can be considered to be isomorphous, but, notwithstanding, the nature of the link between the uranyl–sulfonate and the alkali ion–CB6 complexes changes according to the alkali ion size (the latter cation is disordered in both compounds, see ). In complex 2, the two subunits are hydrogen bonded to one another through the two water molecules complexed to the uranyl ion, which act as hydrogen bond donors toward one carbonyl group and water molecules bound to sodium. In contrast, one of these water molecules (O8) is bridging uranium and cesium ions in 3, resulting in the formation of chains parallel to the [1 1̅ 1̅] axis (with however partial occupancy of the cesium sites). This is one more example of the increase in dimensionality in otherwise very similar structures when going from the smallest to the largest alkali metal ions. The ligand 2-SB2– in 1–3 is chelating, as is the trianion of Tiron in the previously reported complexes. In both ligands, a complexing group (hydroxyl or carboxylic) is located in the ortho position with respect to the sulfonate, and the chelate effect is likely to enforce sulfonate complexation. The sulfobenzoic acids with the substituents in meta and para positions were thus investigated so as to determine if sulfonate bonding could be achieved in the absence of chelation.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Uranyl nitrate has been reacted with 2-sulfobenzoic acid cyclic anhydride and CB6 under hydrothermal conditions either in the absence of another reactant or with addition of alkali metal nitrates, the latter being used both to increase the CB6 solubility and to possibly create bridges between the uranyl complex and CB6 units. In all cases, the sulfonic acid (2-SBH2) was generated in situ from the anhydride and it binds to uranyl in its doubly deprotonated form to give the complexes [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)3]2⋅CB6⋅12H2O (1), [Na(CB6)(H2O)4][UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2⋅NO3⋅3H2O (2), and {[UO2(2-SB)(H2O)2]2Cs(CB6)(OH)(H2O)5}⋅2H2O (3). Compound 2 was obtained in very low yield, which was not improved significantly when heating was prolonged, possibly due to ligand decomposition (decarboxylation or desulfonation). In the absence of an alkali metal, the neutral uranyl complex [UO2(2-SB)(H2O)3] and CB6 are separated (Figure ), but it is however notable that no crystal of this complex could be obtained in the absence of CB6 and under otherwise similar conditions. The uranyl ion is chelated by one carboxylate and one sulfonate oxygen atoms to give a seven-membered ring, and the other three equatorial sites are occupied by water molecules. Chelation occurs also in the sodium- and cesium-containing complexes 2 and 3, with extra bridging by the other carboxylate oxygen atom resulting in the formation of centrosymmetric dinuclear units, and with two water molecules completing the uranium coordination sphere (Figures  and ). The U-O(sulfonate) bond length averaged over all three compounds, 2.384(9) Å, matches the average of 2.38(2) Å for the uranyl sulfonate complexes reported in the CSD. The average U-O(carboxylate) and U-O(water) bond lengths, 2.37(3) and 2.39(3) Å, respectively, are unexceptional. In all cases, the carboxylate group is tilted with respect to the aromatic ring, with dihedral angles of 42.4(2), 49.3(5), and 48.5(7)°, respectively. The uranyl ion is located on one side of the aromatic ring, and the dihedral angle between the uranyl mean equatorial plane and the ring amounts to 65.75(10), 89.52(12), and 88.19(15)° in 1-3, respectively, the rings being thus nearly perpendicular to the mean equatorial plane of the dinuclear complexes. Compounds 2 and 3 have very similar unit cell parameters and can be considered to be isomorphous, but, notwithstanding, the nature of the link between the uranyl-sulfonate and the alkali ion-CB6 complexes changes according to the alkali ion size (the latter cation is disordered in both compounds, see ). In complex 2, the two subunits are hydrogen bonded to one another through the two water molecules complexed to the uranyl ion, which act as hydrogen bond donors toward one carbonyl group and water molecules bound to sodium. In contrast, one of these water molecules (O8) is bridging uranium and cesium ions in 3, resulting in the formation of chains parallel to the [1 1̅ 1̅] axis (with however partial occupancy of the cesium sites). This is one more example of the increase in dimensionality in otherwise very similar structures when going from the smallest to the largest alkali metal ions. The ligand 2-SB2- in 1-3 is chelating, as is the trianion of Tiron in the previously reported complexes. In both ligands, a complexing group (hydroxyl or carboxylic) is located in the ortho position with respect to the sulfonate, and the chelate effect is likely to enforce sulfonate complexation. The sulfobenzoic acids with the substituents in meta and para positions were thus investigated so as to determine if sulfonate bonding could be achieved in the absence of chelation.

elements.content: Both 3- and 4-sulfobenzoic acids were used as alkali metal salts (sodium and potassium, respectively). However, while a uranyl–potassium complex was obtained in the latter case, crystals could only be obtained with the former upon addition of cesium nitrate, which yielded the complex [(UO2)2Cs2(3-SB)3(CB6)(H2O)4.5]·7.5H2O (4). The asymmetric unit corresponds to one formula unit and comprises two crystallographically independent uranium atoms and three 3-SB2– ligands (Figure ). The atoms U1 and U2 are doubly bridged by the carboxylate groups of two ligands, which gives an eight-membered ring of curved shape, with a dihedral angle of 54.18(8)° between the average uranyl equatorial planes. Atom U1 is further chelated by the carboxylate group of another 3-SB2– ligand and bound to the sulfonate oxygen atom O7 of the image of this same ligand through an inversion center, thus giving a second dinuclear subunit with the ligands bridging through their two functionalities. Atom U2 is also bound to a sulfonate oxygen atom (O12) pertaining to one of the former, carboxylate-bridging molecules, and to two water molecules. The average U–O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.34(4) and 2.474(2) Å for bridging and chelating groups, respectively, and the average U–O(sulfonate) and U–O(water) bond lengths of 2.376(12) and 2.41(2) Å are unexceptional. This uranyl bonding by 3-SB2– ligands yields a two-dimensional subunit parallel to the (1 0 1̅) plane (Figure ). The total point symbol for the five-nodal net given by the TOPOS software is {4.162}2{42.164}{4}2, with the first symbol corresponding to both U2 and the second ligand (containing S2), the second symbol to U1 and the last to the other two ligands. A simplified view of this subunit is given in Figure . The two cesium atoms are bound to the CB6 molecule and to its image through the screw axis. Cs1 is bound to three carbonyl groups from one molecule and one from the other, while Cs2 is bound to two and five groups from the same CB6 molecules, with however some bond lengths being quite large (Table ). Cs2 is at only 0.279(2) Å from one O6 portal, while Cs1 is at 1.522(2) Å from the closer, tridentate one. Water molecules complete the coordination sphere of both atoms, one of them being bridging (O34). The [Cs2(CB6)] complex thus forms columns parallel to the b axis, with each CB6 molecule being tilted with respect to its neighbors by 31.61(3)°. The uranyl–organic sheets are linked to one another by these columns through bonding of Cs1 to the sulfonate oxygen atom O13, which results in the formation of a three-dimensional framework (Figures and ). It is interesting to note that one finds once more here the association of uranyl–organic two-dimensional subunits and alkali or alkaline-earth metal ion–CB6 columns, which appears as a quite general trend and has been found in particular when long-chain dicarboxylates were used as ligands for uranyl ions. In the present case, bonding of the cesium ions to the pendent sulfonate groups creates links between these two subunits, turning an alternation of parallel one- and two-dimensional assemblies into a three-dimensional framework. As previously noted, the propensity of uranyl ions to form planar coordination polymers, due to the equatorial positioning of its ligands, and that of CB6 molecules to stack into columns are well matched with one another, and the units thus formed readily crystallize together.
elements.clean_text: Both 3- and 4-sulfobenzoic acids were used as alkali metal salts (sodium and potassium, respectively). However, while a uranyl-potassium complex was obtained in the latter case, crystals could only be obtained with the former upon addition of cesium nitrate, which yielded the complex [(UO2)2Cs2(3-SB)3(CB6)(H2O)4.5]⋅7.5H2O (4). The asymmetric unit corresponds to one formula unit and comprises two crystallographically independent uranium atoms and three 3-SB2- ligands (Figure ). The atoms U1 and U2 are doubly bridged by the carboxylate groups of two ligands, which gives an eight-membered ring of curved shape, with a dihedral angle of 54.18(8)° between the average uranyl equatorial planes. Atom U1 is further chelated by the carboxylate group of another 3-SB2- ligand and bound to the sulfonate oxygen atom O7 of the image of this same ligand through an inversion center, thus giving a second dinuclear subunit with the ligands bridging through their two functionalities. Atom U2 is also bound to a sulfonate oxygen atom (O12) pertaining to one of the former, carboxylate-bridging molecules, and to two water molecules. The average U-O(carboxylate) bond lengths of 2.34(4) and 2.474(2) Å for bridging and chelating groups, respectively, and the average U-O(sulfonate) and U-O(water) bond lengths of 2.376(12) and 2.41(2) Å are unexceptional. This uranyl bonding by 3-SB2- ligands yields a two-dimensional subunit parallel to the (1 0 1̅) plane (Figure ). The total point symbol for the five-nodal net given by the TOPOS software is {4.162}2{42.164}{4}2, with the first symbol corresponding to both U2 and the second ligand (containing S2), the second symbol to U1 and the last to the other two ligands. elements.content: The complex obtained with 4-sulfobenzoic acid, [UO2K2(4-SB)2(CB6)(H2O)9]·11H2O (5), is a molecular species that displays an unusual shape (Figure ). In contrast to all other compounds, crystals of 5 were not obtained while the reaction solution was heated, but upon its cooling down. The uranyl ion is bound to two monodentate carboxylate groups from two 4-SB2– ligands which are in cis positions in the equatorial plane, and to three water molecules. The average U–O(carboxylate) and U–O(water) bond lengths of 2.337(2) and 2.44(2) Å are in the usual range. One of the pendent sulfonate groups is bound to atom K1, with a bond length of 2.737(4) Å close to the average value from the CSD, 2.79(13) Å (range 2.57–3.26 Å). This atom is further bound to three carbonyl groups from CB6, with an average bond length of 2.73(10) Å, identical to that recently measured in another tridentate CB6 complex, and to two water molecules (one of them doubly hydrogen bonded to CB6). A second potassium ion is bound to three carbonyl groups from the other CB6 portal, with an average bond length of 2.80(10) Å, and to four water molecules (some of them disordered). Although many potassium complexes with CB5 are known, few with CB6 are reported in the CSD, and they correspond to bi- or tridentate bonding with an average K–O bond length of 2.79(13) Å. The [UO2(4-SB)2(H2O)3]2– unit is folded over the CB6 molecule, although these two parts of the complex are not directly linked by hydrogen bonding. The water molecules bound to uranyl are involved in hydrogen bonds with sulfonate, carbonyl, and water oxygen atoms of neighboring molecules, with a single intramolecular bond between O15 and the uncoordinated carboxylate atom O4. The molecules are stacked head-to-tail along the b axis, so as to minimize the steric interactions.

elements.content: Sulfonate groups are thus coordinated to uranyl in the complexes formed with 2- and 3-SB2– (1–4), while they are only bound to potassium in the case of 4-SB2– (5). Sulfonate bonding to uranyl is possibly enforced, or at least facilitated, by chelation effects in the 2-SB2– complexes, but these are absent in the 3-SB2– complex, and, although sulfonate is coordinated, carboxylate bonding is predominant in this case in terms of the number of donor atoms. It thus appeared interesting to investigate a sulfonate ligand in which no carboxylate group was present, so as to avoid coordination sites with such a high affinity for uranyl. This could be done with 1,2-ethanedisulfonic acid (EDSH2), used as its disodium salt, which gave the complex [(UO2)4(EDS)(OH)6(CB6)(H2O)2]·8H2O (6). The asymmetric unit comprises two uranyl ions, half an EDS2– dianion, and half a CB6 molecule, both located around inversion centers, as well as three bridging hydroxide groups (O8–O10), and coordinated and free water molecules (Figure ). The sulfonate group is bridging the two uranium atoms through its atoms O5 and O6, in a slightly asymmetric way, with an average U–O bond length of 2.49(4) Å, slightly larger (albeit not quite significantly) than those in the previous complexes but in agreement with the average value of 2.455(7) Å in the complex with bridging ethanesulfonate anions reported in the CSD. The EDS2– dianion thus connects four uranyl centers, the two uranium atoms bound to each sulfonate being also bridged by an hydroxide ion (O8), thus creating a six-membered ring. Atom U1 is further bound to one carbonyl group of CB6, with a bond length of 2.528(3) Å, which is in the usual range [2.337(6)–2.545(6) Å], and its coordination sphere is completed by two more hydroxide ions (O9 and its equivalent O9i through the inversion center) which link U1 to its symmetry-equivalent U1i. Atom U2 is also doubly bridged by two hydroxide ions (O10, O10j) to its symmetry-equivalent U2j, and it is also bound to a water molecule. The average U–O(hydroxide) bond length of 2.34(2) Å and the average U–O(hydroxide)–U angle of 119(11)° are in agreement with the average values from the CSD, 2.33(3) Å and 114(11)°. Uranyl bridging by the three hydroxide ions thus creates cationic [(UO2)2(OH)3]+ undulated chains parallel to the [0 1 1̅] axis in which one hydroxide (O8) singly bridges [(UO2)2(OH)2]2+ dinuclear units. The chains are then connected to one another by the disulfonate anions to give a two-dimensional network parallel to the bc plane, which displays large [(UO2)8(EDS)2(OH)10] rings (Figure ). These sheets are further connected to one another by CB6 molecules to build a seven-nodal three-dimensional framework, a simplified representation of which is given in Figure . When viewed down the a axis, the CB6 molecules project at the center of the rings, which makes the packing as compact as possible. As can be seen in the two views of Figure , the overall arrangement displays an alternation of uranyl–organic and CB6 layers, and it is highly reminiscent of the architectures found in some compounds comprising uranyl complexes with long-chain dicarboxylates and CB6 complexes with alkaline-earth metal ions, although, in the present case, the CB6 molecules are linked to the sheets by coordination bonds and do not form columnar coordination polymers. It is notable that, in 6, each ligand, hydroxide, EDS2– and CB6, brings about an additional increase in the dimensionality of the system (at least from a purely structural viewpoint, since the formation of the framework is not likely to proceed by such simple steps).

elements.content: The little studied complexation of uranyl ions by sulfonates has been investigated in the presence of CB6, with the expectation that the latter would facilitate the crystallization of the uranyl–sulfonate complex. It was possible indeed to obtain six compounds uniting these components, while no crystalline uranyl complex with these sulfonates could be obtained in the absence of CB6 under similar conditions. The complexes with the three positional isomers of sulfobenzoic acid display a clear trend: while the carboxylate group is always coordinated to uranyl, sulfonate may or may not be bound depending on the isomer considered, chelation effects enforcing its coordination with the ortho, but not with the meta and para isomers. In the only case of the three-dimensional framework with the EDS2– disulfonate ligand is uranyl bonding to CB6 observed, likely as a result of the absence of alkali metal ions, for which CB6 has much affinity. It is notable that sulfonate complexation to uranyl is achieved under hydrous conditions, generally not considered to be favorable for such a weak ligand, which suggests that sulfonates may be interesting molecules for the synthesis of uranyl–organic coordination polymers or frameworks under hydrothermal conditions. The architectures of the three-dimensional frameworks 4 and 6 deserve particular notice since both of them display an alternation of uranyl–organic planar sheets with CB6 columns or layers. These are new examples of the ready association between these two components, whether interacting with each other through weak interactions or, as in the present cases, linked to one another by coordination bonds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The little studied complexation of uranyl ions by sulfonates has been investigated in the presence of CB6, with the expectation that the latter would facilitate the crystallization of the uranyl-sulfonate complex. It was possible indeed to obtain six compounds uniting these components, while no crystalline uranyl complex with these sulfonates could be obtained in the absence of CB6 under similar conditions. The complexes with the three positional isomers of sulfobenzoic acid display a clear trend: while the carboxylate group is always coordinated to uranyl, sulfonate may or may not be bound depending on the isomer considered, chelation effects enforcing its coordination with the ortho, but not with the meta and para isomers. In the only case of the three-dimensional framework with the EDS2- disulfonate ligand is uranyl bonding to CB6 observed, likely as a result of the absence of alkali metal ions, for which CB6 has much affinity. It is notable that sulfonate complexation to uranyl is achieved under hydrous conditions, generally not considered to be favorable for such a weak ligand, which suggests that sulfonates may be interesting molecules for the synthesis of uranyl-organic coordination polymers or frameworks under hydrothermal conditions. The architectures of the three-dimensional frameworks 4 and 6 deserve particular notice since both of them display an alternation of uranyl-organic planar sheets with CB6 columns or layers. These are new examples of the ready association between these two components, whether interacting with each other through weak interactions or, as in the present cases, linked to one another by coordination bonds.

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 2-SBA (18 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 1 appeared within one week (8 mg, 35% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal. Calcd for C50H80N24O44S2U2: C, 26.55; H, 3.57; N, 14.86; S, 2.84. Found: C, 26.72; H, 3.51; N, 15.29; S, 2.69%.

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 2-SBA (18 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of NaNO3 (17 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 2 appeared in low yield within one week.

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol), 2-SBA (18 mg, 0.10 mmol) and CsNO3 (20 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. Light yellow crystals of complex 3 appeared within 24 h (6 mg, 26% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal. Calcd for C50H67CsN24O38S2U2: C, 26.28; H, 2.95; N, 14.71; S, 2.81. Found: C, 25.45; H, 3.02; N, 14.91; S, 2.69%.

CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 3-SBNaH (22 mg, 0.10 mmol), a 20-fold excess of CsNO3 (40 mg, 0.21 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. CB6·5H2O (11 mg, 0.01 mmol), a 10-fold excess of UO2(NO3)2·6H2O (50 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 4-SBKH (24 mg, 0.10 mmol), and demineralized water (1.8 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure. After one week, the solution was left to slowly cool down, which gave light yellow crystals of complex 5 (7 mg, 33% yield on the basis of CB6). Anal.
